          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src458" class="srcSentence">Document windows\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src459" class="srcSentence">There is no need to replicate document windows, because they are provided by the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src460" class="srcSentence"> However, you might decide that you want to leverage the colors used in document windows so that your UI always appears consistent with this part of the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src461" class="srcSentence">When using document window color tokens, you must be careful to use them only for similar elements, and always in pairs.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src462" class="srcSentence"> If you do not do so, you will have unexpected results in your UI.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
            </content>
            <sections>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src463" class="srcSentence">Document window frame\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src464" class="srcSentence">Document windows can be either docked in the IDE or floating as a separate window.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src465" class="srcSentence"> When a document window is floating outside the IDE, it still sits in a document well, and has background, border, text, and tab colors that are the same as when it is part of the IDE.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src466" class="srcSentence"> However, the document sits inside a frame that has its own background, border, and text colors.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src467" class="srcSentence"> When tool windows are docked in the document well, they inherit the behavior and color for their tabs from document window token names.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="e21e8e80-c23c-44d7-8e90-838b51924cda"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <para>
                    <embeddedLabel>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src468" class="srcSentence">Docked document window\</caps:sentence>
                    </embeddedLabel>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="c987829f-72a0-4084-b46f-78add28e75ab"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <para>
                    <embeddedLabel>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src469" class="srcSentence">Floating document window\</caps:sentence>
                    </embeddedLabel>
                  </para>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src470" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src471" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating UI that you want to match the document window.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src472" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src473" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want automatically to change if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>

              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src518" class="srcSentence">Document tabs\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src519" class="srcSentence">Document tabs sit in the tab channel to indicate which documents are currently open, along with which one is the current selected or active document.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src520" class="srcSentence"> Tool windows can also be docked in the document tab channel if the user places them there.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src521" class="srcSentence"> In this situation, they use the same tab colors as document windows.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src522" class="srcSentence"> If you are creating UI that you want to always match the document window colors (including theme updates or if new themes are installed), then reference these color tokens.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="f252c0b0-a5c5-4a2e-bc26-31c24f70aded"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src523" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src524" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating UI that you want to match document tabs and automatically pick up theme updates or new theme colors.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src525" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src526" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don’t want to change automatically when the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                </content>
                <sections>
                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src527" class="srcSentence">Open document tabs\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src528" class="srcSentence">Each open document has a tab in the document tab channel that displays its name.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src529" class="srcSentence"> Documents can be either selected or open in the background, and their tabs reflect these states:\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                      <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src530" class="srcSentence">The selected tab represents the document that is currently displayed in the document well.\</caps:sentence>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src531" class="srcSentence"> A selected tab has a document border that extends across the top edge of the document well.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src532" class="srcSentence">Background tabs are any document tabs that are not the currently selected tab.\</caps:sentence>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src533" class="srcSentence"> Once clicked, they become the selected tab and acquire all background, border, and text colors from those token names.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                      </list>
                      <mediaLink>
                        \<image xlink:href="682e78cb-781c-41fd-a80c-0eaf7020057c"></image>
                      </mediaLink>
                      <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src534" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src535" class="srcSentence">when you are creating custom document tabs.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src536" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <list class="bullet">
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src537" class="srcSentence">for provisional (preview) tabs.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src538" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want to change automatically if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                          </list>
                        </definition>
                      </definitionTable>
                    </content>
                  </section>

                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src576" class="srcSentence">Preview tab\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src577" class="srcSentence">The preview tab appears on the right side of the document tab channel when the user clicks an item in the Solution Explorer tool window.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src578" class="srcSentence"> It acts as a preview of the document and also gives the user the option to keep the document open on the left side of the document tab channel.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src579" class="srcSentence"> Only one preview tab open can be open at a time.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src580" class="srcSentence"> Preview tabs have both background and selected states, like open tabs, and can be focused or unfocused in their active state.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                      <mediaLink>
                        \<image xlink:href="aa15f16e-25cf-4d13-9668-63b3939f9a0e"></image>
                      </mediaLink>
                      <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src581" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src582" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating provisional preview and want some element to match the current preview tab color.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src583" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <list class="bullet">
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src584" class="srcSentence">for any kind of document or tab that is not provisional (preview).\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src585" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want to change automatically if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                          </list>
                        </definition>
                      </definitionTable>

                        <br />
                      </para>

                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src623" class="srcSentence">Document overflow button\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src624" class="srcSentence">The document overflow button is present if there are one or more documents open, regardless of whether there is vertical space in the current configuration to fit all document tabs.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src625" class="srcSentence"> The document overflow drop-down menu, which is controlled by the <legacyBold>CommandBarMenu</legacyBold> colors (see \<link xlink:href="9d3186f3-07d2-441f-b33e-435e95d8a0b8#BKMK_CommandMenus">Menus</link>), displays a list of all open documents, both visible and hidden, and the overflow glyph changes depending on whether all the open documents are displayed in the tab channel.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                      <mediaLink>
                        \<image xlink:href="d44c51aa-b9ad-4988-b1fc-fc1d8307d505"></image>
                      </mediaLink>
                      <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src626" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src627" class="srcSentence">when you are creating a custom document overflow button.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src628" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <list class="bullet">
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src629" class="srcSentence">for UI that is not similar to an overflow button.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src630" class="srcSentence">for command bar overflow buttons.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                          </list>
                        </definition>
                      </definitionTable>
                      <para>
                        <br />
                      </para>

          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src656" class="srcSentence">Tool windows\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src657" class="srcSentence">There is no need to replicate tool windows, because they are provided by the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src658" class="srcSentence"> However, you might decide that you want to leverage the colors used in tool windows so that your UI always appears consistent with this part of the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
              <mediaLink>
                \<image xlink:href="20cc3766-876a-44be-8bc4-49f57f51449c"></image>
              </mediaLink>
              <definitionTable>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src659" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src660" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating UI that you want to match tool windows.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src661" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src662" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want to change automatically if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
              </definitionTable>
            </content>
            <sections>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src663" class="srcSentence">Tool window frame\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src664" class="srcSentence">Tool windows in Visual Studio are used for many different tasks, and can exist in one of several different states.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src665" class="srcSentence"> If a tool window is open, it can be assigned to any of the four sides of the document area.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src666" class="srcSentence"> Tool windows can also float outside of the IDE, which allows them to be repositioned anywhere within the user's screen.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src667" class="srcSentence"> Floating windows always sit on top of the IDE.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src668" class="srcSentence"> Finally, tool windows can be docked as document windows and appear as a tab in the document well.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src669" class="srcSentence"> Tool windows that have been docked as document windows are colored in part using document window token names.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="ca0bc894-e6e0-443e-a9ff-61a0f0be8f7f"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src670" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src671" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating UI that you want to match tool windows.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src672" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src673" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want to change automatically if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>
                  <para>
                    <legacyBold>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src674" class="srcSentence">Docked\</caps:sentence>
                    </legacyBold>
                  </para>
                  <table>

              </section>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src692" class="srcSentence">Tool window title bar\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src693" class="srcSentence">The title bar border is not a true border, but a thick line across the top of the title bar.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src694" class="srcSentence"> It does not have a token name for its unfocused state.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="b048e259-6628-45ce-b276-fd0838d40b64"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src695" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src696" class="srcSentence">anywhere you are creating UI that you want to match tool windows.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src697" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src698" class="srcSentence">for any UI that you don't want to change automatically if the shell has a theme update.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>
                  <para>
                    <legacyBold>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src699" class="srcSentence">Focused\</caps:sentence>
                    </legacyBold>
                  </para>
                  <table>
                    <thead>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src700" class="srcSentence">Component\</caps:sentence>

                          </para>

                          </mediaLink>

                          </para>

          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src832" class="srcSentence">Common shared controls\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src833" class="srcSentence">When you use a standard Visual Studio command bar in your feature, you will have access to styled shell controls, and you should not re-template these common controls.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src834" class="srcSentence"> However, if you need to build a custom command bar, you might need to build custom controls as well.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src835" class="srcSentence"> In that case, make sure to use the correct token names for each of the following controls so that your UI is consistent with the rest of Visual Studio.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
            </content>
            <sections>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src836" class="srcSentence">Search box\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src837" class="srcSentence">Whenever possible, use the common search control provided by the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src838" class="srcSentence"> Search box colors are found in the "SearchControl" category in the <legacyBold>ShellColors.pkgdef</legacyBold> file, which contains token names for the input field, action button, drop-down button, and drop-down menu.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src839" class="srcSentence">A search box can be one of several states, some of which are mutually exclusive:\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <list class="bullet">
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src840" class="srcSentence">"Focused" or "unfocused" refers to whether or not the cursor is in the text box.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src841" class="srcSentence">"Active" or "inactive" refers to whether the user has input a search query in the text box.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src842" class="srcSentence">"Hover" means that the user has moused over the search box with the mouse (this state overrides all other states).\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src843" class="srcSentence">"Disabled" means that search functionality is turned off for the current context.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                  </list>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="b80dc0fe-acea-4e02-928d-fd9887a97f26"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src844" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src845" class="srcSentence">when you are designing a custom search box.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src846" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src847" class="srcSentence">for anything that is not a search box.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src848" class="srcSentence">for anything that you do not want always to match the search box UI.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                      </list>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>
                  <para>

                <sections>
                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src939" class="srcSentence">Search drop-down lists\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src940" class="srcSentence">The search box dropdown menu has the potential to be slightly more complex than other dropdown menus in Visual Studio.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src941" class="srcSentence"> The "suggested searches" and "search options" sections can appear alone or together in the menu and each one is colored separately.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src942" class="srcSentence"> A line also separates these two sections when they appear together and a border surrounds the entire dropdown menu.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                      <mediaLink>
                        \<image xlink:href="a19d3777-32df-4c59-97ff-1186363d968a"></image>
                      </mediaLink>
                      <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src943" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <list class="bullet">
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src944" class="srcSentence">when you are creating a custom search dropdown list.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src945" class="srcSentence">the correct token names for the correct list components.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                          </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                          \<caps:sentence id="src946" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                          <list class="bullet">
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src947" class="srcSentence">for dropdown lists that appear in other contexts.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                            <listItem>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src948" class="srcSentence">in any background/foreground combination other than specified.\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </listItem>
                          </list>
                        </definition>
                      </definitionTable>
                      <para>
                        <br />
                      </para>

              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1001" class="srcSentence">Hyperlink\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1002" class="srcSentence">The hyperlink is one control that does not have a foreground/background pair.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1003" class="srcSentence"> In all cases, use the foreground hyperlink color, which will appear correctly on dark, gray and white backgrounds.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1004" class="srcSentence"> If you do not use the color token for the hyperlink control, you will see the default system color for "pressed,"" which will flash red.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1005" class="srcSentence"> That is the signal that the control is not using the correct environment color token.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="e0f799a4-a0b0-45c6-983a-1a32a05d5442"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1006" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1007" class="srcSentence">when you need to create a custom hyperlink.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1008" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1009" class="srcSentence">for anything that is not a hyperlink.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>
                  <para>

              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1030" class="srcSentence">Infobar\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1031" class="srcSentence">Infobars are used to provide more information about a given context and always appear at the top of a document window or tool window.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="9ee3f809-df03-4a90-9e2c-0762dbeac61c"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1032" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1033" class="srcSentence">when creating custom infobars.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1034" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1035" class="srcSentence">for UI elements that are not similar to an infobar.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <table>
                    <thead>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1036" class="srcSentence">Component\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1037" class="srcSentence">Element\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>

                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>

                          </mediaLink>
                          <para>
                            <embeddedLabel>
                              \<caps:sentence id="src1039" class="srcSentence">Infobar\</caps:sentence>
                            </embeddedLabel>
                          </para>
                        </TD>

                          </para>
                        </TD>

              </section>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1043" class="srcSentence">Scroll bar\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1044" class="srcSentence">Scroll bars are styled by the Visual Studio environment, and will not need to be themed.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1045" class="srcSentence"> However, you might decide that you want to leverage the colors used in scroll bars so that your UI always appears consistent with this this part of the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="de1243fc-e076-49c5-9e97-7c8a5a97ae65"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1046" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1047" class="srcSentence">when you are creating UI that you want to match Visual Studio scrollbars.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1048" class="srcSentence">Do not use ...\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1049" class="srcSentence">for anything you don't want to always match scrollbar UI.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>

              <section address="BKMK_TreeView">
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1083" class="srcSentence">Tree view\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1084" class="srcSentence">Several tool windows, including the Solution Explorer, Server Explorer, and Class View, implement a hierarchical organizational scheme whose colors are controlled by color names in the TreeView category.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1085" class="srcSentence"> All items in a tree view have background and text colors.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1086" class="srcSentence"> Items that have nested child elements also have glyphs that indicate whether the item is expanded or collapsed.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="cd3f4f66-0490-443d-a1af-6a9a455c293c"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1087" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1088" class="srcSentence">anywhere you need to implement a hierarchical organizational view.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1089" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1090" class="srcSentence">for anything that is not similar to a tree view.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1091" class="srcSentence">in any background/foreground combination other than specified.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                      </list>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <para>
                    <br />
                  </para>

                    </definedTerm>

                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1152" class="srcSentence">for buttons in the document well that you want to integrate with Visual Studio themes (Light, Dark, Blue, or a system High Contrast theme).\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>

              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1296" class="srcSentence">Tabular data (grid) controls\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1297" class="srcSentence">Tabular data controls, also known as grid controls, are common controls for Visual Studio that can be used to present large amounts of data in multiple columns.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1298" class="srcSentence"> Standard tabular data controls can be found in multiple places within Visual Studio: the Error List tool window, IntelliTrace reports, and memory heap view, among others.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1299" class="srcSentence"> Always use the standard tabular data controls provided.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1300" class="srcSentence"> In some rare instances, you might not have access to the standard tabular data controls.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1301" class="srcSentence"> In these situations, use the following token names to ensure that your UI is consistent with other tabular data controls in Visual Studio.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="de4f8596-354a-4ce2-a4ad-bce5bbcf1ce5"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1302" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1303" class="srcSentence">for tabular or grid controls.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1304" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1305" class="srcSentence">for any UI that is not a tabular or grid control.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                </content>
                <sections>
                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1306" class="srcSentence">Column headers\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>

                  <section>
                    <title>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1326" class="srcSentence">List view items\</caps:sentence>
                    </title>
                    <content>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1327" class="srcSentence">List view items consist of a background and the content.\</caps:sentence>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1328" class="srcSentence"> The content can be text, an icon, or both.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                      <table>
                        <thead>
                          <tr>
                            <TD>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src1329" class="srcSentence">State\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </TD>
                            <TD>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src1330" class="srcSentence">Element\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </TD>
                            <TD>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src1331" class="srcSentence">Token name: Category.color\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </TD>
                          </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                          <tr>
                            <TD rowspan="3">
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src1332" class="srcSentence">Default\</caps:sentence>
                              </para>
                            </TD>
                            <TD>
                              <para>
                                \<caps:sentence id="src1333" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>

          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src1348" class="srcSentence">Manifest Designer\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1349" class="srcSentence">The Manifest Designer was designed as a way to make it easier to edit the manifest file in Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8 projects.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1350" class="srcSentence"> While there is no shared framework available for consumption, it might be appropriate for you to match the design layout and colors of the orientation/navigation tabs and overall structure.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1351" class="srcSentence"> For more information about layout details, see \<link xlink:href="c19e3022-047c-43b6-a046-a82717efed4f">Layout for Visual Studio</link>.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
              <mediaLink>
                \<image xlink:href="6bb5cdec-651d-42af-8649-93374ac1056e"></image>
              </mediaLink>
              <definitionTable>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1352" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <list class="bullet">
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1353" class="srcSentence">for designers that are similar to the Manifest Designer.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1354" class="srcSentence">in place of using common tab controls at the top of an editor within the document well.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                  </list>
                </definition>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1355" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <list class="bullet">
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1356" class="srcSentence">if you have more than six tabs.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                    <listItem>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1357" class="srcSentence">for any UI that is not structured like the Manifest Designer.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </listItem>
                  </list>
                </definition>
              </definitionTable>

          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src1379" class="srcSentence">Tagging\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1380" class="srcSentence">Visual Studio supports tagging, which allows a user to declare searchable keywords for tracking purposes.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1381" class="srcSentence"> For example, project managers and developers can use Team Foundation Server (TFS) to tag work items.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1382" class="srcSentence"> The tables below give color names for both the tag itself and the "close icon" glyph that appears in hover and selected states.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
              <mediaLink>
                \<image xlink:href="246e4206-e877-4433-9a48-faf01b1e35bd"></image>
              </mediaLink>
              <definitionTable>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1383" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1384" class="srcSentence">for UI that supports tagging.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1385" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1386" class="srcSentence">for any other type of UI.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
              </definitionTable>
            </content>

          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src1452" class="srcSentence">Shell\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para></para>
            </content>
            <sections>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1453" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1454" class="srcSentence">The environment background consists of two layers.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1455" class="srcSentence"> The bottom layer is a solid color that covers the entire IDE.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1456" class="srcSentence"> The top layer fits under the command shelf and between the tool window auto-hide channels on the left and right edges of the IDE.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1457" class="srcSentence"> As of Visual Studio 2013, the top and bottom background layers are set to the same color in the Light and Dark themes.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="6d773dae-d7c2-40ca-aec7-be07771aec59"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1458" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1459" class="srcSentence">for places that you want to match the background of the Visual Studio environment.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1460" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1461" class="srcSentence">as a fill for places that are not background surfaces.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1462" class="srcSentence">as a background on which you wish to place foreground elements.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                      </list>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <table>
                    <thead>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1463" class="srcSentence">Component\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1464" class="srcSentence">Element\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1465" class="srcSentence">Token name: Category.color\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                    </thead>
                    <tbody>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1466" class="srcSentence">Bottom layer\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1467" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>

                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.EnvironmentBackground</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                    </tbody>
                  </table>

                            \<caps:sentence id="src1468" class="srcSentence">Component\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>

                          </para>

                          </para>

                            \<caps:sentence id="src1472" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                          <para>
                            <legacyItalic>
                              \<caps:sentence id="src1473" class="srcSentence">Gradient stops set to the same color value in Visual Studio 2013 Light and Dark themes.\</caps:sentence>
                            </legacyItalic>
                          </para>

                          </para>

                            <codeInline>Environment.EnvironmentBackgroundGradientMiddle1</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>

              </section>
              <section>
                <title>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1474" class="srcSentence">Command shelf\</caps:sentence>
                </title>
                <content>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1475" class="srcSentence">Two sets of token names are used for the command shelf backgrounds: one set for where the menu bar sits and one for where the command bars sit.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1476" class="srcSentence"> An individual command bar group has its own background color values, which are discussed in more detail in the "command bar" section.\</caps:sentence>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1477" class="srcSentence"> Menu bar and command bar text is discussed in the menu and command bar sections, respectively.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                  <mediaLink>
                    \<image xlink:href="00544c7d-a451-4b33-80ce-cc438e99f13a"></image>
                  </mediaLink>
                  <definitionTable>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1478" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1479" class="srcSentence">for areas where you place menus or toolbars.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1480" class="srcSentence">with the correct background/​foreground token name combination.\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </listItem>
                      </list>
                    </definition>
                    <definedTerm>
                      \<caps:sentence id="src1481" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                    </definedTerm>
                    <definition>
                      <para>
                        \<caps:sentence id="src1482" class="srcSentence">for areas that are not similar to a command shelf.\</caps:sentence>
                      </para>
                    </definition>
                  </definitionTable>
                  <table>
                    <thead>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1483" class="srcSentence">Component\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1484" class="srcSentence">Element\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1485" class="srcSentence">Token name: Category.color\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                    </thead>
                    <tbody>
                      <tr>
                        <TD rowspan="3">
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1486" class="srcSentence">Menu bar\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD rowspan="3">
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1487" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                          <para>
                            <legacyItalic>
                              \<caps:sentence id="src1488" class="srcSentence">Gradient stops set to the same color value in Visual Studio 2013 Light and Dark themes.\</caps:sentence>
                            </legacyItalic>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfHighlightGradientBegin</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfHighlightGradientMiddle</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfHighlightGradientEnd</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                      <tr>

                            \<caps:sentence id="src1489" class="srcSentence">Command bar\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD rowspan="3">
                          <para>
                            \<caps:sentence id="src1490" class="srcSentence">Background\</caps:sentence>
                          </para>
                          <para>
                            <legacyItalic>
                              \<caps:sentence id="src1491" class="srcSentence">Gradient stops set to the same color value in Visual Studio 2013 Light and Dark themes.\</caps:sentence>
                            </legacyItalic>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfBackgroundGradientBegin</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfBackgroundGradientMiddle</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                      <tr>
                        <TD>
                          <para>
                            <codeInline>Environment.CommandShelfBackgroundGradientEnd</codeInline>
                          </para>
                        </TD>
                      </tr>
                    </tbody>
                  </table>
                </content>
              </section>
            </sections>
          </section>
          <section>
            <title>
              \<caps:sentence id="src1492" class="srcSentence">Toolbox\</caps:sentence>
            </title>
            <content>
              <para>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1493" class="srcSentence">The toolbox is one of the common tool windows that is most frequently used in Visual Studio.\</caps:sentence>
                \<caps:sentence id="src1494" class="srcSentence"> It is essentially a tree control with a special theme and styling applied.\</caps:sentence>
              </para>
              <mediaLink>
                \<image xlink:href="28d2a6f2-5ae8-45b1-9627-a2f300862592"></image>
              </mediaLink>
              <definitionTable>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1495" class="srcSentence">Use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1496" class="srcSentence">when you are designing a tool window that you want to always be consistent with the shell toolbox.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
                <definedTerm>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1497" class="srcSentence">Do not use …\</caps:sentence>
                </definedTerm>
                <definition>
                  <para>
                    \<caps:sentence id="src1498" class="srcSentence">for anything that is not similar to the toolbox UI, or if you are unsure whether your UI will have problems if the shell toolbox colors change.\</caps:sentence>
                  </para>
                </definition>
              </definitionTable>
              <para>
                <br />
              </para>
              <para>
                <legacyBold>
                  \<caps:sentence id="src1499" class="srcSentence">Default\</caps:sentence>
                </legacyBold>
              </para>
